<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 278, 326, 294]]<|/det|>
## ADDITIONAL MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 154, 314]]<|/det|>
Paper 1  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[707, 278, 905, 294]]<|/det|>
0606/13  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[707, 300, 905, 315]]<|/det|>
October/November 2018

2 hours

Candidates answer on the Question Paper.

Additional Materials: Electronic calculator  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 390, 388, 407]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 416, 719, 432]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 432, 320, 447]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 447, 504, 462]]<|/det|>
You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 462, 504, 477]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 476, 380, 491]]<|/det|>
DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 502, 282, 516]]<|/det|>
Answer all the questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 516, 828, 546]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place in the case of angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 545, 593, 560]]<|/det|>
The use of an electronic calculator is expected, where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 560, 603, 575]]<|/det|>
You are reminded of the need for clear presentation in your answers.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 585, 603, 600]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 600, 759, 615]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 615, 437, 630]]<|/det|>
The total number of marks for this paper is 80.

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[401, 73, 594, 91]]<|/det|>
Mathematical Formulae  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 165, 559, 183]]<|/det|>
## 1. ALGEBRA  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 196, 233, 214]]<|/det|>
Quadratic Equation  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 226, 371, 245]]<|/det|>
For the equation \(a x^{2} + b x + c = 0,\)  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[415, 243, 583, 280]]<|/det|>
\[x = \frac{-b\pm\sqrt{b^{2} - 4ac}}{2a}.\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 301, 222, 319]]<|/det|>
Binomial Theorem  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[252, 322, 745, 361]]<|/det|>
\[(a + b)^{n} = a^{n} + \binom{n}{1} a^{n - 1}b + \binom{n}{2} a^{n - 2}b^{2} + \ldots +\binom{n}{r} a^{n - r}b^{r} + \ldots +b^{n},\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 368, 490, 408]]<|/det|>
where \(n\) is a positive integer and \(\binom{n}{r} = \frac{n!}{(n - r)!r!}\)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[405, 470, 591, 489]]<|/det|>
## 2. TRIGONOMETRY  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 502, 153, 520]]<|/det|>
Identities  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[420, 530, 580, 600]]<|/det|>
\[\sin^{2}A + \cos^{2}A = 1\] \[\sec^{2}A = 1 + \tan^{2}A\] \[\csc^{2}A = 1 + \cot^{2}A\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 630, 235, 647]]<|/det|>
Formulae for \(\Delta ABC\)  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[408, 653, 588, 686]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{a}{\sin A} = \frac{b}{\sin B} = \frac{c}{\sin C}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[408, 705, 590, 725]]<|/det|>
\[a^{2} = b^{2} + c^{2} - 2bc\cos A\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 732, 556, 761]]<|/det|>
\[\Delta = \frac{1}{2} bc\sin A\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 78, 99, 98]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 78, 144, 98]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 76, 920, 102]]<|/det|>
In the expansion of \(\left(2 + p x\right)^{5}\) the coefficient of \(x^{3}\) is equal to \(- \frac{8}{25}\) . Find the value of the constant \(p\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 95, 920, 114]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 450, 144, 470]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 444, 645, 475]]<|/det|>
Find the term independent of \(x\) in the expansion of \(\left(2x^{2} + \frac{1}{4x^{2}}\right)^{8}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 450, 920, 470]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[319, 84, 675, 233]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 253, 920, 289]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows a sector \(POQ\) of a circle, centre \(O\), radius \(r\mathrm{cm}\), where angle \(POQ = \theta\) radians. The perimeter of the sector is \(20\mathrm{cm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 301, 144, 320]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 301, 648, 320]]<|/det|>
Show that the area, \(A \mathrm{cm}^2\), of the sector is given by \(A = 10r - r^2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 303, 920, 320]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 580, 559, 598]]<|/det|>
It is given that \(r\) can vary and that \(A\) has a maximum value.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 612, 143, 630]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 612, 562, 630]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(\theta\) for which \(A\) has a maximum value.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 612, 920, 630]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 97, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 432, 88]]<|/det|>
Do not use a calculator in this question.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 463, 120]]<|/det|>
In this question, all lengths are in centimetres.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 133, 710, 151]]<|/det|>
A triangle \(ABC\) is such that angle \(B = 90^{\circ}\), \(AB = 5\sqrt{3} + 5\) and \(BC = 5\sqrt{3} - 5\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 165, 143, 183]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 165, 520, 183]]<|/det|>
Find, in its simplest surf form, the length of \(AC\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 165, 920, 183]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 504, 143, 522]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 504, 777, 522]]<|/det|>
Find \(\tan BCA\), giving your answer in the form \(a + b\sqrt{3}\), where \(a\) and \(b\) are integers.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 504, 920, 522]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 680, 91]]<|/det|>
In this question, the units of \(x\) are radians and the units of \(y\) are centimetres.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 384, 121]]<|/det|>
It is given that \(y = (1 + \cos 3x)^{10}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 131, 143, 151]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 128, 421, 153]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(\frac{\mathrm{dy}}{\mathrm{dx}}\) when \(x = \frac{\pi}{2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 131, 920, 150]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 504, 593, 525]]<|/det|>
Given also that \(y\) is increasing at a rate of \(6 \mathrm{cm s}^{- 1}\) when \(x = \frac{\pi}{2}\),

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 535, 141, 554]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 534, 475, 554]]<|/det|>
find the corresponding rate of change of \(x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 534, 920, 553]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 92, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 920, 107]]<|/det|>
A particle \(P\) is moving in a straight line such that its displacement, \(s\) m, from a fixed point \(O\) at time \(t\) s, is given by \(s = 12\mathrm{e}^{- 0.5t} + 4t - 12.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 119, 143, 136]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 119, 547, 136]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(t\) when \(P\) is instantaneously at rest.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 119, 920, 137]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 288, 143, 306]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 288, 564, 306]]<|/det|>
Find an expression for the acceleration of \(P\) at time \(t\) s.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 288, 920, 306]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[106, 473, 143, 491]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 473, 589, 491]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(s\) when the acceleration of \(P\) is \(0.3 \mathrm{m s}^{- 2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 473, 920, 491]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 766, 143, 784]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 765, 662, 784]]<|/det|>
Explain why the acceleration of the particle will always be positive.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 766, 920, 784]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 92, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[139, 87, 855, 255]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 273, 920, 312]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows a quadrilateral \(OABC\). The point \(D\) lies on \(OB\) such that \(\overrightarrow{OD} = 2\overrightarrow{DB}\) and \(\overrightarrow{AD} = m\overrightarrow{AC}\), where \(m\) is a scalar quantity.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[349, 317, 648, 339]]<|/det|>
\[\overrightarrow{OA} = \mathbf{a}\qquad \overrightarrow{OB} = \mathbf{b}\qquad \overrightarrow{OC} = \mathbf{c}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 354, 143, 371]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 352, 398, 371]]<|/det|>
Find \(\overrightarrow{AD}\) in terms of \(m\), \(\mathbf{a}\) and \(\mathbf{c}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 355, 920, 373]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 460, 141, 479]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 460, 376, 479]]<|/det|>
Find \(\overrightarrow{AD}\) in terms of \(\mathbf{a}\) and \(\mathbf{b}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 462, 920, 480]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[106, 632, 141, 650]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 632, 531, 650]]<|/det|>
Given that \(15\mathbf{a} = 16\mathbf{b} - 9\mathbf{e}\), find the value of \(m\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 632, 920, 650]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 92, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 73, 507, 101]]<|/det|>
\[\mathrm{f}(x) = 5 + \sin \frac{x}{4}\quad \mathrm{for}\quad 0\leqslant x\leqslant 2\pi \mathrm{radians}\]

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 104, 393, 131]]<|/det|>
\[\mathrm{g}(x) = x - \frac{\pi}{3}\quad \mathrm{for}\quad x\in \mathbb{R}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 139, 144, 158]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 138, 381, 158]]<|/det|>
Write down the range of \(\mathrm{f}(x)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 139, 920, 158]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 262, 143, 281]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 260, 440, 281]]<|/det|>
Find \(\mathrm{f}^{-1}(x)\) and write down its range.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 262, 920, 281]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[106, 477, 141, 496]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 477, 311, 497]]<|/det|>
Solve \(2\mathrm{fg}(x) = 11\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 477, 920, 496]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 84, 94, 103]]<|/det|>
<label>9</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 75, 920, 109]]<|/det|>
Find the equation of the normal to the curve \(y = \frac{\ln(3x^2 + 1)}{x^2}\) at the point where \(x = 2\), giving your answer

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 112, 920, 135]]<|/det|>
in the form \(y = mx + c\), where \(m\) and \(c\) are correct to 2 decimal places. You must show all your working. [8]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 104, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 87, 910, 377]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 406, 880, 428]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the curve \(y = 12 + x - x^2\) intersecting the line \(y = x + 8\) at the points \(A\) and \(B\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 440, 143, 459]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 440, 477, 459]]<|/det|>
Find the coordinates of the points \(A\) and \(B\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 440, 920, 459]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 670, 143, 688]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 667, 339, 692]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 670, 920, 688]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 71, 616, 88]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 72, 920, 88]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 75, 104, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>11</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 905, 109]]<|/det|>
The polynomial \(\mathrm{p}(x) = ax^{3} + 17x^{2} + bx - 8\) is divisible by \(2x - 1\) and has a remainder of \(-35\) when divided by \(x + 3\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 120, 143, 139]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 120, 695, 140]]<|/det|>
By finding the value of each of the constants \(a\) and \(b\), verify that \(a = b\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 120, 920, 139]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 494, 341, 512]]<|/det|>
Using your values of \(a\) and \(b\),

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 523, 141, 543]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 523, 703, 543]]<|/det|>
find \(\mathrm{p}(x)\) in the form \((2x - 1)\mathrm{q}(x)\), where \(\mathrm{q}(x)\) is a quadratic expression,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 523, 920, 542]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]
